  1. Mathematical Analysis I
  2. 2. Functions and Their Graphs, Elementary Functions and Properties

2. Functions and Their Graphs, Elementary Functions and Properties

Author

Zakhar Podyakov

Published

September 18, 2025

1. Summary

1.1 Core Concepts of Functions

A function is a rule that assigns a single, unique output to every input. The set of all permissible inputs is called the domain, and the set of all resulting outputs is the range. If a function f takes an input x to produce an output y, we write \(y = f(x)\).

  • Implicit Domain: When a function is defined by a formula without a specified domain, the domain is assumed to be the largest set of real numbers for which the formula gives real-valued outputs. For example, for \(f(x) = \frac{1}{x-2}\), the domain is all real numbers except \(x=2\).
  • Graph of a Function: The graph is a visual representation consisting of all points \((x, f(x))\) on the Cartesian plane. The value \(f(x)\) represents the height of the graph at point \(x\). The formal definition of the graph is the set \(\{(x, f(x)) | x \in D\}\), where \(D\) is the domain.
1.2 Special Step Functions: Floor and Ceiling
  • Floor Function (Greatest Integer Function): Denoted \(\lfloor x \rfloor\), this function rounds a number down to the greatest integer less than or equal to \(x\). For example, \(\lfloor 3.7 \rfloor = 3\) and \(\lfloor -2.1 \rfloor = -3\).
  • Ceiling Function (Least Integer Function): Denoted \(\lceil x \rceil\), this function rounds a number up to the smallest integer greater than or equal to \(x\). For example, \(\lceil 3.7 \rceil = 4\) and \(\lceil -2.1 \rceil = -2\).
1.3 Function Behavior: Monotonicity

A function is monotone on an interval if it consistently increases or decreases.

  • Increasing: \(f(x_1) \le f(x_2)\) whenever \(x_1 < x_2\).
  • Strictly Increasing: \(f(x_1) < f(x_2)\) whenever \(x_1 < x_2\).
  • Decreasing: \(f(x_1) \ge f(x_2)\) whenever \(x_1 < x_2\).
  • Strictly Decreasing: \(f(x_1) > f(x_2)\) whenever \(x_1 < x_2\).

A function that is strictly monotone (either strictly increasing or strictly decreasing) on its domain is guaranteed to be one-to-one.

1.4 Combining Functions

Functions can be combined arithmetically or through composition. For arithmetic combinations, the domain is the intersection of the individual domains.

  • Arithmetic Operations: \((f+g)(x) = f(x)+g(x)\); \((f-g)(x) = f(x)-g(x)\); \((fg)(x) = f(x)g(x)\); and \((f/g)(x) = f(x)/g(x)\), with the added domain restriction that \(g(x) \neq 0\).
  • Composition: The composition \((f \circ g)(x)\) is defined as \(f(g(x))\). The input \(x\) must be in the domain of \(g\), and the output \(g(x)\) must be in the domain of \(f\). The order of composition is critical, as \((f \circ g)(x)\) is generally not equal to \((g \circ f)(x)\).
1.5 Inverse Functions
  • One-to-One Function: A function is one-to-one if no two distinct inputs produce the same output. This can be verified visually with the horizontal line test—if no horizontal line intersects the graph more than once, the function is one-to-one.
  • Inverse Function: If a function \(f\) is one-to-one, it has an inverse function, denoted \(f^{-1}\), that “reverses” its action. If \(f(a) = b\), then \(f^{-1}(b) = a\). The domain of \(f^{-1}\) is the range of \(f\), and the range of \(f^{-1}\) is the domain of \(f\). The graph of \(f^{-1}\) is a reflection of the graph of \(f\) across the line \(y=x\).
1.6 Function Symmetry: Even and Odd Functions

For a function to be even or odd, its domain must be symmetric about the origin (if \(x\) is in the domain, \(-x\) must also be).

  • Even Function: \(f\) is even if \(f(-x) = f(x)\). Its graph is symmetric with respect to the y-axis (e.g., \(f(x) = x^2\), \(f(x) = \cos x\)).
  • Odd Function: \(f\) is odd if \(f(-x) = -f(x)\). Its graph is symmetric with respect to the origin (e.g., \(f(x) = x^3\), \(f(x) = \sin x\)).

Any function with a symmetric domain can be uniquely decomposed into the sum of an even and an odd function:

  • Even Part: \(f_{\text{even}}(x) = \frac{f(x) + f(-x)}{2}\)
  • Odd Part: \(f_{\text{odd}}(x) = \frac{f(x) - f(-x)}{2}\)
1.7 Elementary Functions
1.7.1 Power, Polynomial, and Rational Functions
  • Power Function: A function of the form \(f(x) = x^a\), where \(a\) is a real number. This includes integer powers (\(x^2\)), roots (\(x^{1/2} = \sqrt{x}\)), and reciprocals (\(x^{-1} = 1/x\)).
  • Polynomial Function: A sum of power functions with non-negative integer exponents: \(p(x) = a_n x^n + \dots + a_1 x + a_0\). The highest exponent \(n\) is the degree of the polynomial.
  • Rational Function: A ratio of two polynomials, \(f(x) = \frac{p(x)}{q(x)}\). Its domain excludes any values of \(x\) for which \(q(x)=0\).
1.7.2 Exponential and Logarithmic Functions
  • Exponential Function: \(f(x) = a^x\), where the base \(a > 0\) and \(a \neq 1\). Its domain is all real numbers, and its range is \((0, \infty)\).
  • Logarithmic Function: \(f(x) = \log_a(x)\), the inverse of the exponential function. The expression \(\log_a(x)\) gives the exponent to which the base \(a\) must be raised to obtain \(x\). Its domain is \((0, \infty)\), and its range is all real numbers.
1.7.3 Trigonometric Functions and Their Inverses

Trigonometric functions relate an angle \(\theta\) to the coordinates \((x, y)\) of a point on a circle of radius \(r\). They are periodic, meaning their values repeat.

  • Definitions: \(\sin \theta = y/r\), \(\cos \theta = x/r\), \(\tan \theta = y/x\), etc.
  • Periodicity: The period of \(\sin x, \cos x, \sec x, \csc x\) is \(2\pi\). The period of \(\tan x\) and \(\cot x\) is \(\pi\).
  • Inverse Trigonometric Functions: Because they are not one-to-one, we must restrict the domain of trigonometric functions to create their inverses (e.g., \(\arcsin x\), \(\arccos x\)). For example, \(\arcsin x\) is defined for inputs in \([-1, 1]\) and produces an angle in \([-\pi/2, \pi/2]\).
1.7.4 Hyperbolic Functions and Their Inverses

Hyperbolic functions are combinations of exponential functions and are analogous to trigonometric functions.

  • Definitions: \(\sinh x = \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{2}\) and \(\cosh x = \frac{e^x + e^{-x}}{2}\). The other four are defined similarly to their trigonometric counterparts (e.g., \(\tanh x = \sinh x / \cosh x\)).
  • Inverse Hyperbolic Functions: These are the inverses of the hyperbolic functions (with domain restrictions where needed, like for \(\cosh x\)). They can be expressed using natural logarithms. For instance, \(\text{arsinh}(x) = \ln(x + \sqrt{x^2+1})\).

2. Definitions

  • Function: A rule assigning each input from a domain to exactly one output.
  • Domain: The set of all possible input values for a function.
  • Range: The set of all possible output values of a function.
  • One-to-One Function: A function where each output corresponds to a unique input.
  • Inverse Function (\(f^{-1}\)): A function that reverses the mapping of a one-to-one function.
  • Even Function: A function satisfying \(f(-x) = f(x)\), symmetric about the y-axis.
  • Odd Function: A function satisfying \(f(-x) = -f(x)\), symmetric about the origin.
  • Periodic Function: A function that repeats its values at regular intervals (the period).
  • Polynomial: A function expressed as a sum of non-negative integer powers of a variable.
  • Degree of a Polynomial: The highest exponent of the variable in a polynomial.
  • Rational Function: A function that is the ratio of two polynomials.
  • Exponential Function: A function of the form \(f(x) = a^x\) where \(a\) is a positive constant.
  • Logarithmic Function: The inverse of an exponential function, \(f(x) = \log_a(x)\).
  • Hyperbolic Functions: Functions defined as combinations of \(e^x\) and \(e^{-x}\), such as \(\sinh x\) and \(\cosh x\).
  • Composition of Functions: An operation \((f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x))\) where one function is applied to the result of another.

3. Formulas

  • Even Part of a Function: \(f_{\text{even}}(x) = \frac{f(x) + f(-x)}{2}\)
  • Odd Part of a Function: \(f_{\text{odd}}(x) = \frac{f(x) - f(-x)}{2}\)
  • Composition: \((f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x))\)
  • Pythagorean Identities:
    • \(\sin^2 x + \cos^2 x = 1\)
    • \(1 + \tan^2 x = \sec^2 x\)
    • \(1 + \cot^2 x = \csc^2 x\)
  • Angle Addition Formulas:
    • \(\sin(x \pm y) = \sin x \cos y \pm \cos x \sin y\)
    • \(\cos(x \pm y) = \cos x \cos y \mp \sin x \sin y\)
  • Hyperbolic Identity: \(\cosh^2 x - \sinh^2 x = 1\)
  • Hyperbolic Definitions:
    • \(\sinh x = \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{2}\)
    • \(\cosh x = \frac{e^x + e^{-x}}{2}\)
  • Inverse Trig Complementary Angles: \(\arcsin x + \arccos x = \frac{\pi}{2}\)
  • Logarithmic Forms of Inverse Hyperbolic Functions:
    • \(\text{arsinh}(x) = \ln(x + \sqrt{x^2+1})\)
    • \(\text{arcosh}(x) = \ln(x + \sqrt{x^2-1})\) for \(x \ge 1\)
    • \(\text{artanh}(x) = \frac{1}{2} \ln\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)\) for \(|x| < 1\)
  • Change of Logarithm Base: \(\log_b a = \frac{\ln a}{\ln b}\)

4. Mistakes

  • Confusing Inverse Notation for a Reciprocal: Interpreting \(f^{-1}(x)\) as \(1/f(x)\). Why it’s wrong: The \(-1\) superscript denotes an inverse function, which “undoes” the function’s operation. For example, \(\sin^{-1}(x)\) is \(\arcsin(x)\), whereas \((\sin x)^{-1}\) is \(1/\sin x = \csc x\).
  • Assuming Function Composition is Commutative: Thinking that \(f(g(x))\) is always the same as \(g(f(x))\). Why it’s wrong: The order of operations matters. Applying function \(g\) then function \(f\) is a different sequence of transformations than applying \(f\) then \(g\).
  • Incorrectly Simplifying Logarithms: Applying rules that don’t exist, such as writing \(\ln(a+b)\) as \(\ln(a) + \ln(b)\). Why it’s wrong: Logarithm rules apply to products, quotients, and powers, not sums or differences. The correct rule is \(\ln(ab) = \ln(a) + \ln(b)\).
  • Mixing Up Trigonometric and Hyperbolic Identities: Believing that \(\sinh^2 x + \cosh^2 x = 1\). Why it’s wrong: While analogous, the main hyperbolic identity has a minus sign: \(\cosh^2 x - \sinh^2 x = 1\). This difference stems from their definitions using exponential functions.
  • Ignoring the Domain and Range of Inverse Trig Functions: Calculating \(\arcsin(\sin(2\pi))\) as \(2\pi\). Why it’s wrong: The range of \(\arcsin(x)\) is restricted to \([-\pi/2, \pi/2]\). The correct evaluation is \(\sin(2\pi) = 0\), and \(\arcsin(0) = 0\). The formula \(\arcsin(\sin(x)) = x\) is only valid for \(x\) within the restricted range.
  • Forgetting to Find the Domain of a Composite Function Correctly: To find the domain of \(f(g(x))\), only considering the domain of the final simplified function. Why it’s wrong: The domain must satisfy two conditions: \(x\) must be in the domain of the inner function \(g\), and the output \(g(x)\) must be in the domain of the outer function \(f\).

5. Examples

5.1. Domain of a Composite Function
Question: Let \(f(x) = \sqrt{x-4}\) and \(g(x) = x^2\). Find the domain of \((f \circ g)(x)\).
Click to see the solution
  1. Write the composite function: \[ (f \circ g)(x) = f(g(x)) = f(x^2) = \sqrt{x^2 - 4} \]
  2. Determine the domain condition for the outer function f: The input to \(f(u) = \sqrt{u-4}\) must be greater than or equal to 4. So, \(u \ge 4\).
  3. Apply this condition to the inner function g(x): The output of \(g(x)\), which is \(x^2\), becomes the input for \(f\). Therefore, we must have: \[ x^2 \ge 4 \]
  4. Solve the inequality: Taking the square root of both sides gives \(|x| \ge 2\). This means \(x \ge 2\) or \(x \le -2\).
  5. Check the domain of g(x): The domain of \(g(x)=x^2\) is all real numbers, so this adds no further restrictions.
Answer: The domain is \((-\infty, -2] \cup [2, \infty)\).
5.2. Decomposing a Function into Even and Odd Parts
Question: Decompose the function \(f(x) = e^x\) into its even and odd parts.
Click to see the solution
  1. Find \(f(-x)\): \[ f(-x) = e^{-x} \]
  2. Use the formula for the even part: \[ f_{\text{even}}(x) = \frac{f(x) + f(-x)}{2} = \frac{e^x + e^{-x}}{2} \]
  3. Recognize the result: This is the definition of the hyperbolic cosine. \[ f_{\text{even}}(x) = \cosh(x) \]
  4. Use the formula for the odd part: \[ f_{\text{odd}}(x) = \frac{f(x) - f(-x)}{2} = \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{2} \]
  5. Recognize the result: This is the definition of the hyperbolic sine. \[ f_{\text{odd}}(x) = \sinh(x) \]
Answer: The even part is \(\cosh(x)\) and the odd part is \(\sinh(x)\). (Thus, \(e^x = \cosh x + \sinh x\)).
5.3. Proving a Trigonometric Identity
Question: Prove the identity \(\frac{\sin(2x)}{1 + \cos(2x)} = \tan(x)\).
Click to see the solution
  1. Recall the double-angle formulas:
    • \(\sin(2x) = 2 \sin x \cos x\)
    • \(\cos(2x) = \cos^2 x - \sin^2 x\). Another useful form is \(2\cos^2 x - 1\).
  2. Substitute the formulas into the left-hand side: Using the form \(\cos(2x) = 2\cos^2 x - 1\) will be helpful for simplifying the denominator. \[ \frac{2 \sin x \cos x}{1 + (2\cos^2 x - 1)} \]
  3. Simplify the denominator: \[ \frac{2 \sin x \cos x}{2\cos^2 x} \]
  4. Cancel common terms: Cancel the 2 and one factor of cos x from the numerator and denominator. \[ \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} \]
  5. Recognize the result: This is the definition of \(\tan x\). The left side equals the right side.
Answer: The identity is proven.
5.4. Finding an Inverse Function
Question: Find the inverse of the function \(f(x) = 5e^{2x} - 3\).
Click to see the solution
  1. Replace \(f(x)\) with \(y\): \[ y = 5e^{2x} - 3 \]
  2. Swap \(x\) and \(y\): \[ x = 5e^{2y} - 3 \]
  3. Solve for \(y\) by isolating the exponential term: \[ x + 3 = 5e^{2y} \] \[ \frac{x+3}{5} = e^{2y} \]
  4. Take the natural logarithm of both sides: \[ \ln\left(\frac{x+3}{5}\right) = \ln(e^{2y}) \] \[ \ln\left(\frac{x+3}{5}\right) = 2y \]
  5. Isolate \(y\): \[ y = \frac{1}{2} \ln\left(\frac{x+3}{5}\right) \]
  6. Replace \(y\) with \(f^{-1}(x)\): \[ f^{-1}(x) = \frac{1}{2} \ln\left(\frac{x+3}{5}\right) \]
Answer: The inverse function is \(f^{-1}(x) = \frac{1}{2} \ln\left(\frac{x+3}{5}\right)\).
5.5. Using Inverse Trigonometric Relationships
Question: Find the exact value of \(\tan(\arccos(\frac{3}{5}))\).
Click to see the solution
  1. Set up the problem: Let \(\theta = \arccos(\frac{3}{5})\). This means \(\cos(\theta) = \frac{3}{5}\) and \(\theta\) is in the interval \([0, \pi]\).
  2. Visualize with a right triangle: Since \(\cos(\theta)\) is positive, \(\theta\) is in Quadrant I. We can draw a right triangle where the adjacent side is 3 and the hypotenuse is 5.
  1. Find the missing side: Use the Pythagorean theorem to find the opposite side (\(o\)). \[ 3^2 + o^2 = 5^2 \] \[ 9 + o^2 = 25 \] \[ o^2 = 16 \implies o = 4 \]
  2. Calculate the tangent: The problem is now to find \(\tan(\theta)\). From the triangle, \(\tan(\theta) = \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}}\). \[ \tan(\theta) = \frac{4}{3} \]
Answer: \(\frac{4}{3}\).
5.6. Converting Inverse Hyperbolic Functions
Question: Express \(\text{artanh}(1/2)\) in terms of a natural logarithm.
Click to see the solution
  1. Recall the logarithmic formula for artanh(x): \[ \text{artanh}(x) = \frac{1}{2} \ln\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right) \]
  2. Substitute \(x = 1/2\) into the formula: \[ \text{artanh}(1/2) = \frac{1}{2} \ln\left(\frac{1+1/2}{1-1/2}\right) \]
  3. Simplify the fraction inside the logarithm: \[ \frac{1+1/2}{1-1/2} = \frac{3/2}{1/2} = 3 \]
  4. Write the final expression: \[ \text{artanh}(1/2) = \frac{1}{2} \ln(3) \]
Answer: \(\frac{1}{2} \ln(3)\) or \(\ln(\sqrt{3})\).
5.7. Proving an Inverse Trig Identity
Question: Prove that \(\arcsin(-x) = -\arcsin(x)\).
Click to see the solution
  1. Start with the definition: Let \(\theta = \arcsin(-x)\). By definition, this means:
    • \(\sin(\theta) = -x\)
    • \(-\frac{\pi}{2} \le \theta \le \frac{\pi}{2}\)
  2. Manipulate the equation: Multiply both sides of \(\sin(\theta) = -x\) by -1 to get: \[ -\sin(\theta) = x \]
  3. Use the property of the sine function: Sine is an odd function, so \(-\sin(\theta) = \sin(-\theta)\). \[ \sin(-\theta) = x \]
  4. Consider the range: Since \(-\frac{\pi}{2} \le \theta \le \frac{\pi}{2}\), multiplying by -1 reverses the inequalities, giving \(\frac{\pi}{2} \ge -\theta \ge -\frac{\pi}{2}\). The angle \(-\theta\) is also in the valid range for the output of arcsin.
  5. Take the arcsin of both sides: From \(\sin(-\theta) = x\), we can conclude that: \[ -\theta = \arcsin(x) \]
  6. Substitute back: We started with \(\theta = \arcsin(-x)\). Substitute this back into the equation. \[ -(\arcsin(-x)) = \arcsin(x) \] Multiplying by -1 gives the desired identity. \[ \arcsin(-x) = -\arcsin(x) \]
Answer: The identity is proven.
 

Innopolis Mafia 🤘
